titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Thain White Papers 1877-1983
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Elizabeth Cummings Jones
titlestmt.sponsor: Funding for encoding this finding aid was provided through a grant awarded by the National Endowment for the Humanities.

publicationstmt.publisher: Maureen and Mike Mansfield Library, The University of Montana--Missoula,

repository.corpname: University of Montana, Mansfield Library, Archives and Special Collections

did.unittitle: Thain White Papers
did.abstract: Thain White was a Montana historian who focused on the history of western Montana, particularly the Flathead valley. The collection contains maps, artifacts, and documents concerning a variety of Montana historical topics.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Thain White was born and raised in Rollins, Montana. White spent his early years helping his father, Ernie White, raise sheep at White's Columbia Sheep Company. It was during these years that White acquired a strong interest in the history and archeology of his native state. This interest resulted in decades of Montana historical research and writings.

In 1949, Thain and Ernie White began the Flathead Lake Lookout Museum in Lakeside, Montana. Located on the west shore of Flathead Lake, the museum is dedicated to exhibitions and collections concerning regional and primitive artifacts. Two generations of the White family maintained the museum facility until 1972, when the O'Neil Jones family purchased the museum.

During his years as museum director, White undertook a number of research projects concerning the Montana area and the Flathead Valley in particular. He conducted a variety of excavations at battlegrounds from the Indian Wars of the 1880s and homestead sites such as Chimney Coulee. He also focused much of his research on railroads and stage companies existing in Montana at the turn of the century. Much of White's work was done in partnership with Montana State University (now University of Montana) Professor of Anthropology Carling I. Malouf. White documented his research and many of his articles were published together with Malouf by the Flathead Lake Lookout Museum.

scopecontent.p: The collection contains maps, artifacts, and documents concerning a variety of Montana historical topics. Much of the collection is composed of unpublished copies of White's historical articles, as well as notes and research material. White documented and photographed many of his excavations and artifacts and these photos compose a large portion of the collection. The Thain White Papers provide a range of original research on many popular Montana subjects.

arrangement.p: The collection is divided into eight series, two with additional subseries:
Series II: White's Publications, 1.2 linear feet, 1959-1983
Subseries 2: Other Native American Studies, 0.2 linear feet, 1959-1976
Subseries 3: Forts, 0.1 linear feet, 1960-1962 and undated
Series III: Research Material, 0.2 linear feet, undated
Series IV: Other Publications, 0.2 linear feet, 1970-1978
Series VII: Artifacts, 1.0 linear feet and 2 folders, 1906-1960
Subseries 2: Boats and Planes, 0.4 linear feet, 1905-1982
Subseries 3: Soldiers, Indians,and Cowboys, 0.6 linear feet, 1877-1911
Subseries 4: Nature and Animals, 0.2 linear feet, 1898-1973
Subseries 6: Going-to-the-Sun Highway, 0.1 linear feet, circa 1931

accessrestrict.p: Researchers must use collection in accordance with the policies of Archives and Special Collections, the Maureen and Mike Mansfield Library, and The University of Montana--Missoula.

userestrict.p: Researchers are responsible for using in accordance with 17 U.S.C. and any other applicable statutes. Copyright not transferred to The University of Montana.

prefercite.p: Thain White Papers, Archives and Special Collections, Maureen and Mike Mansfield Library, The University of Montana-Missoula.

acqinfo.p: Gift of Thain White, date unknown.

processinfo.p: The actions of the original processors are unknown. In 1999, the collection was re-processed.

separatedmaterial.p: During 1999 processing, the following items were transferred to the Map Division of the Mansfield Library:
Map of the Townsite of Demersville, December 28, 1888.
Map of the Battle of the Bear's Paw. March 28, 1936. Survey by C.R. Noyes. Depicts camps, rifle pits and death points.
Original survey map of the Battle of the Bear's Paw. Drawn in 1935. Survey by C.R. Noyes, staking and point of interest by LV McLohorter, Chief Many Wounds and Chief White Hawk, drawn by Thain White.

did.unittitle: Correspondence

scopecontent.p: A few personal letters, including correspondence between White and Professor Carling Malouf, are contained in this series. Also included is a letter from the Scandinavian-American Hide and Metal Company dated 1915.

did.unittitle: Personal Correspondence
Other Correspondence: Letter from Scandinavian-American Hide and Metal Co.
Other Correspondence
White's Publications

scopecontent.p: Articles on a variety of Montana historical topics constitute this series. White writes on his original research and the collection contains typed, handwritten and published copies. Many of these works were done with the assistance of Professor Carling Malouf. A few of the original copies also include maps and artifacts concerning the research topic. The series is subdivided into six subseries: Indian Wars, Other Native American Studies, Forts, Homesteading, Flathead Valley History and Other Montana Studies. Within these subdivisions, the articles are then arranged alphabetically by topic.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains White's writing and research concerning the armed conflicts between Native American tribes in the Northwest and the United States government.

Research Material

scopecontent.p: This series is composed of a variety of notes and research documents on Montana territory forts and Montana stagecoaches. These works were reference materials for White or unfinished projects. None of this material is dated.

arrangement.p: The series is arranged alphabetically by subject.

Other Publications

scopecontent.p: This small series includes a 1970 publication on steamboats as well as a 1978 tabloid from the Flathead Lookout Museum. The series also contains a few publications on various historical topics.

did.unittitle: Steamboat Bill, Number 114, Summer

Newspaper Clippings

scopecontent.p: White collected a few clippings from Montana newspapers on topics of his interest.

did.unittitle: Newspaper Clippings
Newspaper article spread, composed of articles from the 1870s from a variety of Montana newspapers, (courtesy of the MT Historical Society)
Maps

scopecontent.p: This series consists of a 1939 map of a motor passenger boat for Great Northern Railway and an undated map of a machinery floor plan from the Eureka Lumber Co.

did.unittitle: Maps
Artifacts

scopecontent.p: This series includes impressions and tombstone rubbings, a sample of early twentieth-century sheep and pig tags and a display of materials used to make Indian canoes.

did.unittitle: Impression of an aluminum disk, like the one found at Medicine Rock
Tombstone rubbing from the possible site of the Rains scouting party tragedy
Sheep and pig tags (Ernest White collection)
Display of Indian canoe materials, from Golden Lake, Ontario
Photographs

scopecontent.p: Many of White's articles also included photographs of excavations or relics. Most of these photos were taken by White, although some are prints from the National Archives or the Montana Historical Society. A separation sheet has been included within the collection for those photos that have been removed from White's articles. The photographs include images of a wide variety of Montana subjects, including artifacts, historical places and people, animals and plants, and Glacier National Park. A set of European photos includes images of France and Belgium in the late 1970s.

The photos are divided into six subseries, based on White's arrangement: General; Boats and Planes; Soldiers, Indians, and Cowboys; Nature and Animals; European; and Going-to-the-Sun Highway. The photos have two types of numbers on them, but are intellectually arranged by subject.

did.unittitle: General

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains various photographs, many taken by Thain White, that relate to his research and writing; many are Montana subjects.

did.unittitle: Ethel on Lake McDonald - built by J.W. Swanson in 1911-named after the niece of Frank Kelley-72 ft. long gas launch

Ethel and Lewtana on Lake McDonald. First boat is the Ethel. Second boat is the Lewtana built by J. W. Swanson, formerly the City of Polson when it ran on Flathead Lake. Moved to Lake McDonald via Flathead River

Cassie D on Lake McDonald. Built by Peterson of Kalispell about 1912 and ran on Flathead Lake-then owned by O'Denney-moved to Lake McDonald in 1914-gas launch 54 ft. By 9.5 ft.
Cassie D on Lake McDonald. Built by Peterson of Kalispell about 1912 and ran on Flathead Lake-then owned by O'Denney-moved to Lake McDonald in 1914-gas launch 54 ft. By 9.5 ft.
KEE-O-MEE on Flathead Lake. Built by J.W. Swanson for Bert Saling and Clifford Sherman. Burned in the early 1930s. Gas launch, named by Harry Stanford-means "a long way" in some Indian language
